results.webTitle: Thomasina Miers’ recipe for roast chicken legs with sticky figs, red onions and oloroso vinegar | The new flexitarian

fields.headline: Thomasina Miers’ recipe for roast chicken legs with sticky figs, red onions and oloroso vinegar
fields.standfirst: The fruitful bounty of a Spanish autumn is showcased in this delicious savoury-sweet roast supper
fields.trailText: The fruitful bounty of a Spanish autumn is showcased in this delicious savoury-sweet roast supper
fields.body: While travelling through Spain one October, cooking as I went, I was surprised to see how late the fig season was. Sweet, sticky fruit hung from the laden branches by the hundreds, and we ate them everywhere we went – in syrup, with cheese, baked and fresh. My favourite of all, though, were the figs roasted in savoury guises.
fields.bodyText: While travelling through Spain one October, cooking as I went, I was surprised to see how late the fig season was. Sweet, sticky fruit hung from the laden branches by the hundreds, and we ate them everywhere we went – in syrup, with cheese, baked and fresh. My favourite of all, though, were the figs roasted in savoury guises.

tags.bio: Thomasina Miers is chef and food writer. She is a former MasterChef winner and founder of the Wahaca group of Mexican restaurants

results.webTitle: Rachel Roddy’s recipe for cod with tomatoes and capers | A kitchen in Rome

fields.headline: Rachel Roddy’s recipe for cod with tomatoes and capers
fields.standfirst: A rush of smells and emotions turn into a delicious, hearty, family meal
fields.trailText: A rush of smells and emotions turn into a delicious, hearty, family meal
fields.body: The cod was handsome, fresh and smelled like the sea: salt, iodine and cucumber. Ideally, we would have eaten it straight away, but other plans meant we stored it carefully in the fridge, where it stayed slightly longer than planned. Which meant that, while it was still perfectly good, by the time we came to cook it, a faint fishiness had set in – not unpleasant, but persistent.
fields.bodyText: The cod was handsome, fresh and smelled like the sea: salt, iodine and cucumber. Ideally, we would have eaten it straight away, but other plans meant we stored it carefully in the fridge, where it stayed slightly longer than planned. Which meant that, while it was still perfectly good, by the time we came to cook it, a faint fishiness had set in – not unpleasant, but persistent. Every time anyone opened the fridge, I could see their noses twitch, and thoughts flash across their face. “Dead fish,”

tags.bio: Rachel Roddy is a food writer and author based in Rome
